Exercise

Using cylindrical polar coordinates, integrate the function \(f = z\left(x^2+y^2\right)^{@cc@}\) over the volume between the surfaces \(z=0\) and \(z={@aa + bb*(x^2 + y^2)@}\) for \(0 \le x^2 + y^2 \le {@dd^2@}\). Remember cylindrical polar coordinates are given by the transformation \(x=r\cos\theta \, \), \(y=r\sin\theta \, \), \(z=z.\)

generalfeedback.text:
We are asked to integrate the function \(f = z\left(x^2+y^2\right)^{@cc@}\) over the volume between the surfaces \(z=0\) and \(z={@aa + bb*(x^2 + y^2)@}\) for \(0 \le x^2 + y^2 \le {@dd^2@}\) using cylindrical polar coordinates.

(a) We are first asked to find the Jacobian \(J(r,\theta,z)\) for this transformation.

Using cylindrical polar coordinates means we have

\(\qquad \displaystyle x = r\cos \theta, \quad y = r\sin \theta, \quad \text{and} \quad z=z\)

Evaluating the partial derivatives,

\( \dfrac{\partial x}{\partial r}= \cos \theta, \qquad \dfrac{\partial x}{\partial \theta}= -r \sin \theta, \qquad\dfrac{\partial x}{\partial z}= 0\)

\( \dfrac{\partial y}{\partial r}= \sin \theta, \qquad\dfrac{\partial y}{\partial \theta}= r \cos \theta, \qquad \dfrac{\partial y}{\partial w}= 0\)

\( \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial r}= 0, \qquad \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial \theta}= 0, \qquad \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial z}= 1\)

so the Jacobian is

\[\left| \begin{array}{ccc} \dfrac{\partial x}{\partial r} & \dfrac{\partial x}{\partial \theta} & \dfrac{\partial x}{\partial z} \\ \\ \dfrac{\partial y}{\partial r} & \dfrac{\partial y}{\partial \theta} & \dfrac{\partial y}{\partial z} \\ \\ \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial r} & \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial \theta} & \dfrac{\partial z}{\partial z} \end{array} \right| = \left| \begin{array}{ccc} \cos \theta & -r \sin \theta & 0 \\ \\ \sin \theta & r \cos \theta & 0 \\ \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array}\right| = \left| \begin{array}{ccc} \cos \theta & -r \sin \theta \\ \\ \sin \theta & r \cos \theta \end{array}\right| = {@ta1@} \]

And our Jacobian is therefore \(J = r.\)


(b) To carry out the integration, we now need to find the bounds on our new variables, remembering also that \( r^2 = x^2 + y^2\):

\(\qquad \displaystyle 0 \le z \le {@zlim_cart@} \implies 0 \le z \le {@zlim_cyl@},\)

\(\qquad \displaystyle 0 \le x^2 + y^2 \le {@dd^2@} \implies 0 \le r^2 \le {@dd^2@},\) and so \(0 \le r \le {@dd@},\)

and since \(0 \le x^2 + y^2 \le {@dd^2@}\) describes a disc of radius \({@dd@}\) centred at the origin, we have\(\quad \displaystyle 0 \le \theta \le 2\pi\).

Our function \(f = z\left(x^2+y^2\right)^{@cc@}\) becomes \(f = {@z*r^(2*cc)@}\).

We can now therefore carry out the integration, remembering to include our Jacobian:

\(\begin{align} I &= \int_0^{2\pi} \int_0^{@dd@} \int_0^{@zlim_cyl@} {@exp_cyl@} \,\, r \, \mathrm{d}z \,\mathrm{d}r \, \mathrm{d}\theta \\ &= \int_0^{2\pi} \int_0^{@dd@} \int_0^{@zlim_cyl@} {@exp_cyl_J@} \,\, \mathrm{d}z \,\mathrm{d}r \, \mathrm{d}\theta \\ &= \int_0^{2\pi} \int_0^{@dd@} r^{@2*cc + 1@} \left[\dfrac{1}{2} z^2 \right]_0^{@zlim_cyl@} \, \mathrm{d}r \, \mathrm{d}\theta \\ &= \int_0^{2\pi} \int_0^{@dd@} \left({@inn1@}\right) \, \mathrm{d}r \, \mathrm{d}\theta \\ &= \int_0^{2\pi} \left[{@I2@}\right]_{0}^{@dd@} \, \mathrm{d}\theta \\ &= \int_0^{2\pi} {@inn2@} \, \mathrm{d}\theta \\ &= 2\pi \times {@inn2@} \\ &= {@ta2@}. \end{align}\)
